title: Was ancient India more technologically & scientifically advanced than the western countries? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes and no. Ancient Indians were good free thinkers and produced a lot of new ideas in all major branches of science but few of these ever resulted in useful technology as far as I know. This was because knowledge transmission suffered bottlenecks due to the famous Indian reluctance to maintain records and transmit them freely. This is where Greece and China trumped India. These two civilizations were avid record keepers, particularly the Chinese. In addition, their secular knowledge was less mixed with religion and mysticism than Indians’. Technology is application of scientific knowledge to practical applications. Both Chinese and the Greeks excelled at this. However, Indian economic output remained huge, as much as 30% of the world economy for a in 1st century AD. The reason was not technology but the climate of India. Hot humid summers and mild winters permitted Indians to cultivate crops year round without making any effort to improve agricultural efficiency. Much of Europe could manage only one crop a year. This kept Europe poor till they started using their brains to bring their harsh climate under their control. While Greeks, Romans and Chinese executed irrigation projects to improve their agricultural efficiency, Indians relied on rain gods and conducted homas and yagas to please the rain god. India has been traditionally an exporter or cash crops and food grains. India could export so much food also because those who actually produced food were largely lower castes and untouchables who traditionally not supposed to consume beyond their basic needs. It was like keeping 30–40% of your population enslaved without having to chain them up — their minds willingly enslaved them. Caste system in India also prevented horizontal transmission of knowledge. While both Chinese and Greek societies had their own class systems, and slavery, these were not religiously dictated so were immutable. Thus it was possible for geniuses to emerge from lower classes and even from among slaves, particularly among the ancient Greeks and Romans. Such slaves were given freedom and full citizenship. Thus ancient Indians, despite having the best opportunities and resources in the ancient world, mostly sat over them for centuries and let other civilizations overtake them. Conclusion: Two factors prevented Indian technology from developing like that of the Chinese or the Greeks. (a) poor record keeping affected transmission of knowledge, and (b) caste system that prevented spreading of knowledge which was transmitted only vertically, that too by word of mouth, seldom horizontally. These deficiencies remained hidden at first due to the natural bounty that made high yield out of lazy farming. But the climatic advantage that Indians enjoyed started disappear about 700 years ago, which saw the per capita income of Western Europeans exceed that of India, Middle East and China, and this differential continued to increase.
